title: What Keystone are Pros using during LCS games
body:
Hey all this is just a personal request and if you agree with me lets try and get this thread some popularity.  While watching LCS this weekend i noticed that there is no indicator of what Keystone the players are running.  While in some cases you can tell when you see a thunderlords proc or the caster points something out about the mastery, we have no other idea of what keystone is being used.  With Keystones being a huge part of League right now i believe it would be a good idea for Riot to show which Keystone is being used by the players during LCS/LPL/LCK etc.  Yes, we all know that a majority of champions are using Thunderlords, but with hopeful nerfing and buffing of masteries this will change and other Keystones will become very relevant.  
Thanks everyone for stopping by!

Definitely would like a box somewhere on the match overlay telling Keystones for us viewing the pro matches

As for which keystones, it's not the 8+ Thunderlords That we saw leading up to 6.1.  according to the Match Histories
The trend seems to be the following:

* Tanks outside of bot lane (And Fighters in Top Lane) are primarily taking Grasp of the Undying. 
* Junglers are the most varied,  taking Thunderlord's on Elise and Kindred, Fervor of Battle on Lee Sin, and Strength of Ages on Rek'Sai.
* Mage, regardless of lane are definitely taking Thunderlord's, with the biggest variation being their Tier 2 mastery in Cunning (Secret Stash vs Assassin), and their Tier 3 and 4 Ferocity Masteries. 
* In Bot lane, ADCs seem to universally be taking Fervor of Battle. Tanky Supports are grabbing Bond of Stone. the Mage Support types as mentioned above, are taking Thunderlord's
* There are a few exceptions though. In Immortals vs Team Impulse of W1D2, Immortals' Bot lane did take some alternatives. WildTurtle took Thunderlord's on Corki and Adrian took Windspeaker's Blessing on Janna

And i believe that would be the best part of the indicator!  It would help us get in the head of the pros and see how they choose what keystone depending on matchups and team comps.  All in all a learning point for players!  Thanks man!

Why would you take fervor or battle as Lee Sin?
With Lee Sin you want to burst the enemy so Thunderlord's is quite good for him.

Well, Fervor of Battle is 2 stack per Damaging Ability hit on enemy, 2 per **melee** Auto. Lee Sin get's that 40% ASPD boost for two autos after using an ability. Considering, that both portions of Lee Sin's Q deals Damage, that's 4 stacks right away, 4 more from the double AA hit, and he still has an E for more damage and the Slow, and of course the R. 

 In other words, in about 1 or 2 seconds, Lee Sin will have the Max 8 stacks when he comes to gank the enemy. And of course his ability to pull off twitch reflex jukes with W, Re-engage with Q again since you have a 6 second window to hit an enemy champion again.

TL:DR version: Lee Sin get's it for the same reason someone like Master Yi does, Quick and Easy max stacks.

I agree that it would be nice to see them during the game but if you are curious you can currently check them out after the game by going to the "esports" page and clicking on the game you want to see for example http://www.lolesports.com/en_US/na-lcs/na_2016_spring/matches/regular_season/TSM-vs-CLG

Then you go to the "view player builds and stats" which brings you to a page like you would see in your own match history http://matchhistory.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/#match-details/TRLH1/1001520070?gameHash=e5a089b1818d40b0&tab=overview

From there you can click "player builds" and select each champion to see what masteries they had that game.
I like the idea, but if you really want to know just go to the game statistics after it's over
